title: Resource Annotator
introduction: Use the annotator tool to mark up each source and caption. You can use up to five pins for each theme.

themes.title: Yes
themes.tooltip_text: Source provides strong evidence the Fish Wars were resolved

themes.title: Maybe
themes.tooltip_text: Source leaves open the question of whether the Fish Wars were resolved

sources.title: Mel Moon
sources.body: “We had to go through a period of adjustment to try to learn how to work together. And that was very difficult for the state [Washington State]. They had a tough time trying to realize that the tribe was a comanager. ‘One day they were nobody, and now, I'm supposed to talk to them and manage the fisheries?’”
sources.excerpt: “We had to go through a period of adjustment to try to learn how to work together. And that was very difficult for the state [Washington State]. They had a tough time trying to realize that the tribe was a comanager. ‘One day they were nobody, and now, I'm supposed to talk to them and manage the fisheries?’”
sources.question_text:
What are the requirements of a successful partnership?

What do you think the relationship between tribes and the state of Washington was like at first?
sources.resource_caption: Caption: The state of Washington had difficulty accepting the validity and success of traditional Native knowledge of fisheries management.

sources.title: Carol Craig
sources.body: “Now the tribes are finally being acknowledged as comanagers of the fisheries resources. I had a lot of sports fishermen come directly up to me. And they put out their hand and they said, ‘Would you please tell the Yakama Nation thank you? Because we know if it wasn’t for their tribe, there’d still be no fish in that river.’”
sources.excerpt: “Now the tribes are finally being acknowledged as comanagers of the fisheries resources. I had a lot of sports fishermen come directly up to me. And they put out their hand and they said, ‘Would you please tell the Yakama Nation thank you? Because we know if it wasn’t for their tribe, there’d still be no fish in that river.’”
sources.question_text: Why might it have been so difficult for the public to acknowledge the expertise of Native Nations in their management of salmon habitat?
sources.resource_caption: Caption: Attitudes were slow to change, until sports fishers saw the return of salmon in Washington State’s waters.

sources.body: “Boldt’s ruling, upheld by the U.S. Supreme Court, did more than affirm Indian fishing rights. It upheld treaties as being supreme over state law, as stated in the U.S. Constitution. It established treaty tribes as co-managers of the salmon fishery. And, as Muckleshoot Tribe attorney Alan Stay said, ‘It spawned other actions designed to protect salmon—because if there is no salmon fishery, then the treaty is violated.’”
sources.source: Credit: Richard Walker, “Boldt Revisited,” The News Tribune, February 12, 2014.
sources.excerpt: “Boldt’s ruling, upheld by the U.S. Supreme Court, did more than affirm Indian fishing rights. It upheld treaties as being supreme over state law, as stated in the U.S. Constitution. It established treaty tribes as co-managers of the salmon fishery. And, as Muckleshoot Tribe attorney Alan Stay said, ‘It spawned other actions designed to protect salmon—because if there is no salmon fishery, then the treaty is violated.’”
sources.question_text:
What does attorney Alan Stay mean when he says that if there is no salmon fishery, then the treaty was violated?

Whose responsibility is it to restore the fisheries?
sources.resource_caption: Caption: It is not common knowledge that the treaties the United States enters into with any nation are constitutionally the “supreme law of the land.”

sources.title: Northwest Indian Fisheries Commission
sources.image_caption: NWIFC is an organization that provides support to twenty treaty tribes in western Washington. Nations within the NWIFC work together to effectively manage and preserve salmon populations.
sources.body: NWIFC is an organization that provides support to twenty treaty tribes in western Washington. Nations within the NWIFC work together to effectively manage and preserve salmon populations.
sources.excerpt: NWIFC is an organization that provides support to twenty treaty tribes in western Washington. Nations within the NWIFC work together to effectively manage and preserve salmon populations.
sources.question_text: What opportunities and challenges might nations encounter when they work together in order to solve problems?

sources.title: Columbia River Inter-Tribal Fish Commission
sources.image_credit: Seal of the Columbia River Inter-Tribal Fish Commission (CRITFC), courtesy of Jeremy Five Crows
sources.body: The Columbia River Intertribal Fish Commission (CRITFC) is made up of Yakama, Warm Springs, Umatilla, and Nez Perce tribes. CRITFC's mission is “to ensure a unified voice in the overall management of the fishery resources, and as managers, to protect reserved treaty rights through the exercise of the inherent sovereign powers of the tribes.”
sources.excerpt: The Columbia River Intertribal Fish Commission (CRITFC) is made up of Yakama, Warm Springs, Umatilla, and Nez Perce tribes. CRITFC’s mission is “to ensure a unified voice in the overall management of the fishery resources, and as managers, to protect reserved treaty rights through the exercise of the inherent sovereign powers of the tribes.”
sources.question_text: What opportunities and challenges might nations encounter when they work together in order to solve problems?

sources.title: Richard Solomon
sources.body: “It's a struggle to deal with Washington Department of Fishery. They still are processing our treaty to death.”
sources.excerpt: “It's a struggle to deal with Washington Department of Fishery. They still are processing our treaty to death.”
sources.question_text: What does Solomon mean by the state “processing our treaty to death”?
sources.resource_caption: Caption: Decades after the Boldt Decision, the state and tribes continue to battle in courts to define treaty rights.

sources.title: Willard Bill Jr.
sources.body: “It’s pretty impressive what people have done in such a short time period. And really a lot of that is tied to the Boldt Decision in us being able to provide for ourselves again, which has been guaranteed in our treaties since the 1850s.”
sources.excerpt: “It’s pretty impressive what people have done in such a short time period. And really a lot of that is tied to the Boldt Decision in us being able to provide for ourselves again, which has been guaranteed in our treaties since the 1850s.”
sources.question_text: In what ways might “being able to provide for ourselves again” mean more than economic security for Native people and Nations?
sources.resource_caption: Caption: In the forty years since the Boldt Decision, tribes have grown in population, influence, and economy. The Puyallup Tribe of Indians, for example, is one of the leading employers of non-Indians in their county.

sources.title: Michael Marchand
sources.body: “A couple times a week, we go catch fish . . . in the Columbia River and we bring them up here and we distribute them to tribal elders so they can actually have salmon again. And for many of them, they haven't had salmon for twenty years.”
sources.excerpt: “A couple times a week, we go catch fish . . . in the Columbia River and we bring them up here and we distribute them to tribal elders so they can actually have salmon again. And for many of them, they haven't had salmon for twenty years.”
sources.question_text: Can you think of a resource that is important to you? If it were to disappear, what would be the consequences?
sources.resource_caption: Caption: Salmon People cease to exist without salmon. To witness the return is spiritually invigorating.

sources.title: Al Ziontz
sources.body: “I regard Boldt as something more than a fishing-rights case. It is an Indian survival case. It is a case that gave the tribes the standing—the power—to sit down at the table with other governments as equals.”
sources.source: Credit: Al Ziontz, attorney, roundtable discussion on the Boldt Decision at Northwest Indian College, July 2005 Critical to the Boldt Decision was the ruling that treaty tribes were comanagers of salmon, along with state and federal governments.
sources.excerpt: “I regard Boldt as something more than a fishing-rights case. It is an Indian survival case. It is a case that gave the tribes the standing—the power—to sit down at the table with other governments as equals.”
sources.question_text: According to Ziontz, the Boldt Decision was not just about fish. What was the cultural and political significance of the Boldt Decision?

sources.title: 2012 State of Our Watersheds Report
sources.body: “Despite massive harvest reductions, strategic use of hatcheries, and a huge financial investment in habitat restoration efforts over the past 40 years, the State of Our Watersheds report shows that we are failing to turn the tide on salmon recovery.”
sources.source: Credit: “2012 State of Our Watersheds Report,” Northwest Indian Fisheries Commission, Olympia, WA http://files.nwifc.org/sow/2012_SOWRpt_091912a.pdf
sources.excerpt: “Despite massive harvest reductions, strategic use of hatcheries, and a huge financial investment in habitat restoration efforts over the past 40 years, the State of Our Watersheds report shows that we are failing to turn the tide on salmon recovery.”
sources.question_text: What obstacles exist that could prevent the Fish Wars from reaching a successful conclusion?
sources.resource_caption: Caption: Every year, treaty tribes in western Washington publish a comprehensive report that outlines the quality of salmon habitats across the region.

sources.title: Greg Colfax
sources.body: “Our water boundaries have shrunk to just a tiny little box. We…Makah fishermen… fished from California into the Bering Sea. And today we're just in the box. And that's not who we are. And it creates a lot of tension among the fishermen. But despite the tension, they're still able to work on the water in a traditional way where everybody gets a fair shot and has a chance to catch their share.”
sources.excerpt: “Our water boundaries have shrunk to just a tiny little box. We…Makah fishermen… fished from California into the Bering Sea. And today we're just in the box. And that's not who we are. And it creates a lot of tension among the fishermen. But despite the tension, they're still able to work on the water in a traditional way where everybody gets a fair shot and has a chance to catch their share.”
sources.question_text: Colfax refers to “tension among the fishermen.” What do you think he means?
sources.resource_caption: Caption: When Boldt ruled that treaties guaranteed fifty percent of the fishing harvest to Indian fishers, including off reservation fishing, he looked to historical maps to determine these usual and accustomed boundaries. Reaching consensus from these maps is a challenge. For instance, the Makah are one of several Native Nations who may have had ancestral hunting and fishing grounds reduced as a result of the Boldt Decision.

sources.title: Wallace Heath
sources.body: “The Boldt Decision came down and all of a sudden people said, ‘I am going fishing,’ and they did. Pretty soon another dash of cold water comes down, and that dash of cold water was that they ran out of fish.”
sources.source: Credit: Wallace Heath, Lummi Aquaculture Project, from roundtable discussion on the Boldt Decision at Northwest Indian College, July 2005
sources.excerpt: “The Boldt Decision came down and all of a sudden people said, ‘I am going fishing,’ and they did. Pretty soon another dash of cold water comes down, and that dash of cold water was that they ran out of fish.”
sources.question_text: How does Heath’s statement address the late Billy Frank Jr.’s declaration that “fifty percent of nothing is nothing”?
sources.resource_caption: Caption: Indians and non-Indians alike felt the sting of salmon depletion; the Boldt Decision did not restore salmon at the pounding of a gavel. Salmon runs are still a fraction of what they used to be.

sources.title: First Salmon Ceremony
sources.image_credit: Photograph by Kari Neumeyer, Information and Education Officer, North Sound Region. From the State of our Watersheds 2016 Report, courtesy of the Northwest Indian Fisheries Commission.
sources.body: Tulalip youth drum during the First Salmon Ceremony.
sources.excerpt: Tulalip youth drum during the First Salmon Ceremony.
sources.question_text: How might future tribal leaders be able to end the Fish Wars?
